titleproper.value: Guide to the Virginia Gardner Papers <num>TAM.100</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Charmaine-Smith Campbell, 1991 & Katja Vehlow, 2001

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-06-26T20:28:35</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

extent.value: in 9 record cartons, one manuscript box and one oversize box.

abstract.value: Virginia Gardner (1904-1992) was a journalist, Communist, and biographer of Louise Bryant. She worked at several midwestern newspapers before joining the <title ns2:type="simple" render="italic">Chicago Tribune</title> in 1930. Around 1937, she joined the Communist Party and was fired from the <title ns2:type="simple" render="italic">Tribune</title> for her union activism in 1940. She then went to work for the Women's Division of the Democratic National Committee in New York and was briefly Executive Secretary of the American Council on Soviet Relations in Washington D.C.. She was active in the Citizens Committee for Harry Bridges, and wrote for the <title ns2:type="simple" render="italic">Federated Press</title> (a labor news service), <title ns2:type="simple" render="italic">The New Masses</title>, <title ns2:type="simple" render="italic">Peoples World</title> (the CPUSA West Coast newspaper) in Los Angeles and the <title ns2:type="simple" render="italic">Daily Worker</title> in New York where she covered the Rosenberg case in 1953. Gardner wrote <title ns2:type="simple" render="italic">The Rosenberg Story</title>in 1954 and <title ns2:type="simple" render="italic">Friend and Lover</title>, a Louise Bryant biography in 1982. The collection includes her correspondence, documentation of her political activities, research materials, manuscripts, autobiographical materials, photographs, and articles.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: <lb/><lb/>Identification of item, date; Virginia Gardner Papers; TAM 100; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by John Marberry, son of Virginia Gardner, in 1990. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 1990.013 and 1990.014.

<list><item><emph render="bold">June 27, 1904:</emph>Born in Sallisaw, Oklahoma. Has two older sisters, Gertrude Miller and Katharine Carson.</item><item><emph render="bold">1910:</emph>Mother dies when she was 10 years old.</item><item><emph render="bold">1921 to 1924:</emph>Attended University of Missouri, graduated with a Bachelor of Journalism.</item><item><emph render="bold">Dec. 17, 1927:</emph>Married Jerome Butler, a socialist newspaperman and copy reader</item><item><emph render="bold">1927:</emph>Employed at the St. Louis Times.</item><item><emph render="bold">May 1927:</emph>Father dies.</item><item><emph render="bold">1929:</emph>Hired by Chicago Tribune.</item><item><emph render="bold">July, 1937:</emph>Married Marion (Red) Marberry whom she described as a leftist who never joined the Party. He was also a newspaperman and wrote three books:Joaquin Miller American Poet (1953); Vicky: A Biography of Victoria Woodhull (1967); The Golden Voice: A Biography of Isaac Kelloch (1947).</item><item><emph render="bold">September, 1937:</emph>"Decided to join the Communist Party."</item><item><emph render="bold">April, 1938:</emph>Joined the Newspaper Guild in Chicago.</item><item><emph render="bold">1938:</emph>Active in Hearst strike in California.</item><item><emph render="bold">1939:</emph>Joined the Communist Party.</item><item><emph render="bold">1939:</emph>Filed charges with the National Labor Relations Board regarding unfair treatment at Chicago Tribune.</item><item><emph render="bold">1939:</emph>Assisted in publishing the Tribunit, a publication of the Chicago Tribune workers.</item><item><emph render="bold">March 22, 1940:</emph>Dismissed from Chicago Tribune, because of involvement in Guild activities at the paper.</item><item><emph render="bold">1940:</emph>Moved to New York where she worked with the Women's Division of the Democratic National Committee.</item><item><emph render="bold">1941:</emph>Voted as lifetime member of the Newspaper Guild.</item><item><emph render="bold">1941:</emph>Acted as Executive Secretary of the Citizens Committee for Harry Bridges (President of the ILWU),in New York City in an attempt to prevent his deportation from the United States.</item><item><emph render="bold">1942:</emph>Moved to Washington D.C.; Divorced Marion (Red) Marberry (January); Begins work at Federated Press, a labor news service; serves as Executive Secretary to the American Council on Soviet Relations, a precursor to the National Council of American Soviet Friendship (NCASF).</item><item><emph render="bold">1943:</emph>Resigned from Federated Press. Began working as Washington correspondent for New Masses.</item><item><emph render="bold">1947:</emph>Resigned from New Masses, and moved to Los Angeles; where she began working for The Peoples World</item><item><emph render="bold">1948:</emph>Subpoenaed to appear before the Tenney Committee (California's Fact-Finding Committee on Un-American Activities).</item><item><emph render="bold">1949:</emph>Wrote a few articles for Masses and Mainstream.</item><item><emph render="bold">1951:</emph>Dismissed from The Peoples World.</item><item><emph render="bold">1952:</emph>Moved back to New York; employed in Jamaica, Queens in a meat packing plant.</item><item><emph render="bold">1954:</emph>The Rosenberg Story, published by Masses and Mainstream.</item><item><emph render="bold">1955:</emph>Began work at the Daily Worker.</item><item><emph render="bold">December 1959:</emph>Resigned from the Worker.</item><item><emph render="bold">Feb.-June 1960:</emph>Worked on staff of Factor, a monthly magazine which covers issues related to psychiatry.</item><item><emph render="bold">1960 to 1962:</emph>Freelanced as a medical writer.</item><item><emph render="bold">1962:</emph>Left the Communist Party.</item><item><emph render="bold">1963 to 1971:</emph>Employed as editorial assistant to Corliss Lamont.</item><item><emph render="bold">1982:</emph>Published <title type="simple" render="italic">Friend and Lover</title>, a biography of Louise Bryant (New York:</item><item><emph render="bold">1984 to 1989:</emph>Worked on her unpublished autobiography.</item><item><emph render="bold">1989:</emph>Grandson, John Dorney dies; in failing health.</item><item><emph render="bold">1992:</emph>Dies in San Diego, January 5th.</item></list>
The collection includes Virginia Gardner's correspondence, documentation of her political activities, research materials, manuscripts, autobiographical materials, photographs, and articles.

Series I: Autobiography61247Scope and Content Note

Series I: Autobiography contains a lengthy and rather personal unpublished untitled autobiographical typescript, related correspondence, and a genealogy and other biographical materials.

Series II: Correspondence is divided into personal (family and friends) and political correspondence and spans the years 1922 to 1990. Personal correspondents include her son John Marberry, her nephew John Gardner, several friends, and boyfriends Brady Pryor, Dud Jarret, Paul Cawthron, Andy Anderson, John McShane, and Milt Rogart and his wife. The political correspondence is with communists, other radicals and several well-known writers, including Bill Allen, Sender A. Garlin, Ammon Hennacy, Corrine Hardesty, Corliss Lamont, Kay Hall Sessions, Frank Spector, John Tessitore, Nick Unger, Harry and Nikki Bridges and William Appleman Williams.

Series III: Political Activities, is divided into two sections: A. General, which contains files on the Rosenberg case, the American Council on Soviet Relations, and Gardner's testimony before various legislative committees; and B. The Harry Bridges Case, which contains clippings, correspondence between Gardner and Harry and Nikki Bridges, and Citizens Committee for Harry Bridges materials related to the campaign to prevent his deportation from the United States.

Series IV: Journalism Career, consists of five chronologically arranged subseries that represent the different newspapers and the various cities in which she lived and worked, and which primarily contain copies of Gardner's articles, and correspondence. The subseries and employment/residence dates are: A. Chicago Tribune(1930-1941); B. Federated Press (Washington D.C., 1942-1943); C. New Masses(Washington D.C., 1943-1947); D. Los Angeles (1947-1952), Peoples World; E. New York (1952-1980s), Daily Workerand after.

Correspondence - to be integrated61083undated366Correspondence - to be integrated61082undated367Correspondence610811969-1971368Correspondence610801972-1975369Correspondence610791977370Correspondence610781978371Correspondence610771979372Correspondence61076198041Correspondence610751981-198242Correspondence61074198343Correspondence61073198444Series VI: Research60819Scope and Content Note

Series VI: Research Files. The files for Friend and Loverconsists of Gardner's extensive and unusually rich research files for her biography of Louise Bryant. Contents include clippings, correspondence and interviews with prominent friends and associates, ephemera, primary source documents including a copy of Bryant's marriage license (to John Reed), and a typescript of the book. The Rosenberg StoryResearch Files contain clippings and other ephemera.

Series VII: Photographs includes photographs of Virginia Gardner from the late 1930s and the early 1980s. Also included in this series are photographs of Robert Dunn, Andrew Dasburg, and Louise Bryant from the early 1910s through late 1950s.
